data.title: Eurovision
data.text:
In the 1970s a fire at the Danmarks Radio studios apparently destroyed the only visual copy the 1964 contest. As a consequence, this Eurovision, like that of 1956, exists only in audio form. If the soundtrack is anything to go by, it looks like the loss fell to the right year as it must be said that 1964's contest was a bit on the boring side. This might perhaps be best summed up by the choice of Matt Monro as the UK entry, yet perversely his was one of the more up-beat and entertaining songs of the night. Most, though, were genteel ballads, all much of a muchness, some almost identical, and very few of any real merit. Bucking this trend were the Netherlands and Germany. Holland gave us an energetic piece of early '60s fun, with luxurious string stabs and a sexy swaying verse. It only scored two points. Meanwhile Germany delivered a frantic dance number, performed by the fantastically named Nora Nova, and incorporating a racy burlesque finalé. Europe hated it: nul points.

Portugal's debut in the contest established the tone of their subsequent entries: a passionate male vocalist and a minor key. Again, nul points. Spain, on the other hand, ditched their passionate men for a passionate woman for their usual rousing, powerful torch-song. The devil has the best tunes and all that. Spain managed to secure a point from winners Italy for their efforts. Italy's song, moody and undeniably beautiful, with some fetching bass-kicks and a martial chorus, was so overwhelmingly affecting on the night that the ensuing audience applause demanded a second curtain-call for singer Gigliola Cinquetti. The BBC even gave an unscheduled repeat of the number the following afternoon.

For each year's songs we apply our points in the 12-10-8 style of the modern contest, irrespective of how the voting functioned at the time. In brackets is the position the song came on the night:

HERE ARE THE VOTINGS

OF THE AVIEW JURY:

12pts

(=13th)

GER Nora Nova

"Man gewöhnt sich so schnell an das Schöne" 10pts

(=10th)

NED Anneke Grönloh

"Jij bent mijn leven" 8pts

(=13th)

POR Antonio Calvário

"Oração" 7pts

(1st)

ITA Gigliola Cinquetti

"Non ho l'età" 6pts

(12th)

ESP Nelly, Tim & Tony (TNT)

"Caracola" 5pts

(7th)

FIN

Lasse Mårtenson

"Laiskotellen" 4pts

(3rd)

MON Romuald

"Où sont-elles passées" 3pts

(8th)

NOR Arne Bendiksen

"Spiral" 2pts

(2nd)

GBR

Matt Monro

"I Love The Little Things"

1pt

(=4th)

LUX Hugues Aufray

"Dès que le printemps revient"

Europe had France in joint-fourth, Austria in sixth, Denmark ninth, Belgium joint-tenth, and Yugoslavia and Switzerland joint-last.

Our host, Lotte Wæver.

Our winner, Nora Nova.

The Dutch entry: Anneke Grönloh.

Europe's winner, Gigliola Cinquetti.

POLITICS

The debut of Portugal this year meant the presence of two fascist nations. Swedish singers boycotted the contest, and there was a stage-invasion after the Swiss entry: a man holding a banner baring the slogan "Boycott Franco & Salazar". Television cut to the scoreboard while the protester was removed. Meanwhile, the contest saw its first singer of a non-indigenous racial type in the form of the Indonesian-descended Dutch entry: Anneke Grönloh.
